title: SEXUAL DIMORPHISM IN SIZE OF VESPERTILIONID BATS

body_text.text: Sexual dimorphism in birds and mammals is a phenomenon that has provoked intense interest. Two explanations (not mutually exclusive) are most commonly given for selection favoring dimorphism. The first, put forth by Charles Darwin, is based on the competition of one sex for the other and the different selective pressures resulting on the competitor and the object of competition (Darwin 1859; see Trivers 1972 and Ralls 1976 for reviews). Trivers argues that the sex contributing most to parental care will be in short supply and hence will be the object of competition. Thus, in most mammalian species, males compete for females. Large size is often advantageous in intraspecific competition, so males tend to be larger than females when competition occurs. The second explanation of sexual dimorphism is that differences between males and females are a means of reducing intraspecific competition for resources, especially food (Amadon 1959; Selander 1966; Storer 1966; Schoener 1967; Earhart and Johnson 1970) .

Vespertilionid bats tend to be sexually dimorphic in size. The differences are slight but are found in many species (see below). Females are larger in all cases where significant differences have been found.

Bats are unique among mammals because they fly. Flight places strict limitations on the size and proportional relationships of different parts of the body; coefficients of variation for wing measurements of bats are lower than those for limb measurements of terrestrial mammals (Long 1968 ). Bats have further undergone a reduction in the size of the extreme anterior and posterior parts of the body, resulting in the reduction of weight and the concentration of mass in the pectoral region. Yet, despite the apparent importance of size, female bats are capable of carrying large young. Near-term embryos commonly weigh 20%-30% of the female's body weight after birth (table 1) . This is a considerable load, and its effect on flight is increased because it is located well posterior to the point of attachment of the wings. Furthermore, females may carry their newborn young to new roosting sites if disturbed after parturition (Davis 1970 ).

Based on these considerations, a different selective basis for the sexual dimorphism of vespertilionid bats has been suggested (Phillips 1966; Jones 1967; Fenton 1972; Baker et al. 1972; Kunz 1974b) . Body size is determined by a compromise between many requirements. In the case of male bats, feeding and roosting habits are probably paramount. For females these same factors are important, but in addition an increase in body size reduces the proportionate load of the fetus or newborn young. Wing size may increase even more, resulting in a reduction of wing loading (grams carried per square centimeter of wing area). In a similar manner, the relative cost of producing milk (measured, for example, as calories per gram female weight) is reduced when females are larger. Further, lactating females consume more food than males (Kunz 1974a) . Large size may permit females to carry a larger quantity of insects in their stomachs. Thus, Amer. Natur. 1978 . Vol. 112, pp. 701-711. (C 1978 All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms several factors related to reproduction favor large females ("Big Mother" hypothesis of Ralls 1976 ).

Seasonal changes (not related to pregnancy) in the weight of vespertilionids living in temperate regions are large (for example, see Beer and Richards 1956; Fenton 1970; Kunz 1974a by the exclusion of juveniles (specimens with unfused phalangeal epiphyses) and by the requirement that all measurements be taken from specimens prepared as museum skins, rather than from live bats or specimens prepared as skeletons or alcoholics. The latter condition was necessary due to the differential shrinkage of limbs under different treatments. All species meeting these conditions were included.

Measurements were made with dial calipers and are accurate to 0.2 mm. Originally a series of 19 skin and skull measurements was used in the analyses. Forearm length was chosen as the primary variable, however, because it is consistently dimorphic, easily measured, and frequently included in systematic studies. It was the only variable measured in some cases. In order to test the second prediction, an estimate of general body size is also necessary. Weight could not be used because it is often unavailable, and its use would require differential treatment of specimens according to reproductive status and time of year. Total body length was also rejected because its inclusion would require reliance on the often idiosyncratic original measurements of many different collectors. Instead, I used the greatest length of the skull, measured from the posterior border of the supraoccipital to the anterior end of the premaxillae. This requires the assumption that growth of the head region is linearly related to total growth, which is often, but not always, true (Gould 1975) . Considering the limited number of measurements that can be taken from a skin and skull, however, skull length is probably the best measure of body size available in this case.
The simplest measure of dimorphism in forearm length is average female length minus

This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms average male length. In comparisons of species that differ greatly in wing size it is necessary to consider general size when analyzing this difference since, for example, a 5-mm difference between sexes in a species with an average forearm length of 30 mm may be much more important than an equal difference in a species with an average length of 100 mm. Accommodation of species of different sizes is usually accomplished by using ratios or, when the variables are used in correlation analyses (as below), by partialling the correlation on average forearm length. This results in the removal of any relationship between the size of the forearm and the absolute difference between female and male sizes. The use of partial correlations, however, or the substitution of ratios for the absolute difference, had little effect on the correlations reported below. Therefore, the phrase "degree of dimorphism" will henceforth refer to the difference between average female and male forearm length.

For the following reasons, relatively few data were taken from the literature: need for samples from restricted geographic areas; inadvisability of combining measurements of two or more investigators; and the reduction by many authors of male and female measurements to a combined mean (table 2) . While diligent search might reveal more, the number of species included is sufficiently large that additional data are unlikely to seriously affect the results reported below.

In order to test the first prediction, that dimorphism will be greater where females carry a larger load of young, I calculated a correlation coefficient for modal number of young/pregnancy versus degree of sexual dimorphism, using the values in table 2. I assume that fetal mass, or the total mass of young before they first fly, increases as the number of young increases. Weights of fetuses and young to test this assumption are not available for the same set of species for which forearm measurements were obtained.
Some measurements were found, however, which permit testing the relationship between number of young per pregnancy and the summed weights of the neonates at birth.

These data are presented in table 1. Both total weight of the neonatal bats and weight proportional to female weight after birth differ significantly between bats bearing one young and those bearing two young. Thus, the weight carried by a female just before birth is probably greater for species bearing more young per pregnancy. Unfortunately, no data were available for species bearing more than two young. Females carry nurselings, at least when disturbed (Davis 1970) , and the sum of the weights of the several young at the age just before they first fly probably represents a larger proportion of the mother's weight than in species bearing a single young (e.g., Grinnell 1918; Johnson 1932; Poole 1936; Bailey 1937; Stegeman 1955; Packard 1956; Stains 1965; Golley 1966 ). Finally, if there is no relationship between number of young and weight borne by the female, no correlation between dimorphism and number of young would be expected. That is, a decrease in the size of each young accompanying an increase in litter size should obscure (rather than augment) a correlation between litter size and degree of dimorphism.

The Spearman rank correlation coefficient, rs, between the number of young per pregnancy and the degree of dimorphism, is .88, P < .0001 ( fig. 1) is an exception; its modal litter size is two (Cockrum 1955) . Its degree of dimorphism is higher than that of any other Myotis, conforming with predictions. Third, Lasiurus cinereus bears two young in contrast to other members of the genus which bear three or more. As predicted, it is less dimorphic than the others.

Antrozous pallidus appears to be exceptional since it is much more dimorphic than any other species bearing two young ( fig. 1 ). Antrozous is also unusual in its foraging habits, however, flying and hovering near the ground in order to prey on large terrestrial arthropods (Ross 1967) . Thus, the wing size to body size relationship may be especially critical and unusually great dimorphism might be expected. (This appears to be contradicted by Davis [1968] who reported a surprising ability for this species to fly despite wing injuries.) Struhsaker (1961) reported that among the species of bats he studied (representing several families) Antrozous had unusually broad, short wings.

The second prediction, that females will have larger wings than males of the same body size, cannot be directly tested because all species examined are dimorphic in body size. Therefore, covariance analyses were performed for several species to "remove" the effect of body size (using skull length as a measure of body size) and to test the significance of the remaining difference, if any, between the "adjusted" mean male and female forearm lengths (Snedecor and Cochran 1967) . The species tested were chosen because of the availability of adequately large series (table 3) . In all but one case, the slope of the regression of forearm length on greatest length of skull for males was not significantly different from that for females, while the adjusted means were significantly different or nearly so (table 3) . Thus in most cases the second prediction is confirmed:

female wings tend to be larger than male wings even when body size is the same. NOTE.-The column for "adjusted means" gives the F value and significance level of the difference in female and male forearm lengths after adjustment to equalize body size. The last column gives F values and significance levels (if <.1) for the test comparing the slope of female forearm length on female body size (skull length) with the slope of the same regression for males. Equality of slopes is an assumption of the comparison of adjusted means. P's in parentheses. * P < .05. ** P < .01. *** P < .001.

polygynous systems, where competition by males for females usually (though not necessarily) leads to strong dimorphism in body size, with males larger. While bat social systems are poorly known, and do include polygyny (Dwyer 1970; Medway 1971;  Bradbury and Emmons 1974), a variety of social systems are represented by the species included in these analyses. Where the systems are known or inferred there appears to be no relationship between social structure and degree of dimorphism. For example, one of the species studied, M. nigricans, is probably polygynous (Myers 1977) ; however, its dimorphism is no greater than other species bearing a single young. Finally, contrary to the common condition among polygynous mammals, females are larger than males.

Thus, Darwinian sexual selection is unlikely to be the reason for the difference in male and female wing size. Ralls (1976) in a review of mammals in which females exceed males in size, also concludes that in general large size of females is not due to competition between the sexes for mates.

The niche-subdivision hypothesis cannot be dismissed by consideration of the evidence presented here. In fact, evidence of sexual differences in diet has been found for M. evotis and M. auriculus (Husar 1976 ). The niche-subdivision hypothesis does not, however, explain the strong correlation between the degree of dimorphism and number of young, nor does it explain why females are consistently larger than males. Furthermore, some evidence suggests that males and females of some of the most dimorphic species are geographically or altitudinally separated during the energy-demanding periods of gestation and lactation (L. cinereus: Dalquest 1943; Vaughan and Krutzsch 1954; Findley and Jones 1964. Lasiurus borealis: Jones et al. 1967 . Eptesicus fuscus: Easterla 1973) . If this is the case, sexual differences in size are unlikely to reflect competition between the sexes for food.

cite_spans.text: Jones 1964. Lasiurus borealis: Jones et al. 1967

body_text.text: Two additional hypotheses proposed for species in which females are larger that might apply to vespertilionids are the following: (1) larger body size enables female bats to maintain a constant body temperature at lower ambient temperatures than males, which would favor rapid development of fetuses (Findley and Traut 1970: Pipistrellus hesperus) ; and (2) greater difference between male and female body size facilitates sexual This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms operative, neither accounts for the strong correlation between degree of dimorphism and litter size, and the second would work equally well for species in which males were larger.

This study has been restricted to the family Vespertilionidae, the members of which are generally small, insectivorous, and have a "fluttering" style of flight. Some members of other families have different aerodynamic relationships (e.g., species of the Molossidae, which have long, narrow wings and fast, straight flight), larger body size, and different foraging habits. These differences complicate the relationship between wing size and body size and may partly explain the unusually great dimorphism of A. pallidus.

Among some large species of molossids, for example, males are larger than females in most dimensions (e.g., Molossus ater : Miller 1913) . It is suggestive that small members of the family (e.g., Molossops temmincki, Eumops bonariensis, Tadarida brasiliensis, T.

limbata, all of size comparable to the vespertilionids studied above) show reduced general dimorphism compared with the larger species (Myers, unpublished data; Fenton 1972 ). In T. limbata the females' wings are actually deeper than the males' (Fenton 1972) . In a large series of T. cyanocephala (table 3) males had bigger skulls (P < .0001), but male and female wing size did not differ significantly (P = .51).

Covariance analysis revealed that female wings would be larger in animals with the same size skull (P < .05). The same was found to be true of E. bonariensis (table 3) . This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms

FIGREF2.text: Several factors support rejecting intraspecific competition for mates as the explanation of sexual dimorphism in the case of vespertilionids. The size differences between sexes are small, and the dimensions of adult males and females overlap considerably.Darwinian sexual selection commonly results in well-marked differences in size, color, and other features. Such are not evident to the human observer in most vespertilionid populations. Further, Darwinian sexual selection should be most pronounced in This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms .4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms .4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:25:51 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms

FIGREF3.text: Members of other families that have slow, fluttering flight, small body size, and that feed on flying insects, should show dimorphism consistent with the predictions presented above. Few data are available but Saccopteryx bilineata, S. leptura, and Rhynchonycteris naso, three Central American species of bats of the family Emballonuridae, fit that description and are dimorphic with females slightly larger than males(Bradbury and Emmons 1974). Similarly, Nycteris hispida (Nycteridae) are dimorphic with females larger, as are female Hipposideros cyclops, H. abae, and H. caffer centralis (Rhinolophidae)(Verschuren 1957), and several members of the family Phyllostomatidae (seeRalls 1976).SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONSSexual dimorphism in body size of mammals is usually explained in terms of competition among members of one sex for members of the other or as a means of reducing intraspecific competition for resources such as food. Sexual dimorphism in vespertilionid bats, often characterized by females exceeding males in body size, does not seem to fit either explanation. A third hypothesis, that female body size is influenced by the need to fly with and nourish large fetuses (and occasionally young), is probably unique to bats. If true, it should follow that the greatest degree of sexual dimorphism would occur in those species bearing the greatest fetal or neonatal weight. Examination of data concerning size (skull and forearm lengths) and reproduction for vespertilionid bats reveals that the total weight and modal number of young born per pregnancy per species are strongly, positively correlated with the degree of sexual dimorphism in wing size. Further, covariance analysis shows that the wings of females of several species of vespertilionids are larger than those of males even after statistical adjustment of the data to make the body size of each sex the same. These observations suggest that sexual dimorphism in size of vespertilionid bats is influenced by the demands of large fetuses.ACKNOWLEDGMENTS I thank Richard D. Alexander, Michael D. Carleton, Katherine G. Dewey, Michael F. Hirshfield, Lora G. Myers, and Robert W. Storer for advice and assistance. The figure was prepared by Mark Orsen.

TABREF1.text: ). The pattern of change, however, is similar for each sex, although of course female weights are slightly larger.
TABREF1.content:
If the extra mass related to reproduction carried by females is important in deter-
mining their body size (and especially their wing size) relative to males, two con-
sequences might be expected. The first is that a greater degree of sexual dimorphism
should be found in those species in which females carry or feed a greater mass of fetal
tissue or young. This dimorphism should be particularly evident in wing size, but may
also apply to general body dimensions. If it exists, this relationship supports the role of
the extra mass related to reproduction in determining sexual dimorphism. It is not
expected to result from intersexual competition for mates or resources, but if verified it
does not eliminate the possibility that these are important. The second prediction based
on this hypothesis is that if males and females had the same body size female wings
would still be larger than male wings. Obviously, this relationship is not necessarily
required, since any increase in the body size of females results in a decrease in the
proportionate weight carried (Ralls 1976) and the cost of lactation. Nevertheless, if
confirmed, the relationship is consistent with and provides support for the hypothesis
that the sexual dimorphism in size of vespertilionid bats is related to the extra mass
females carry during pregnancy and lactation.
METHODS
Original measurements and measurements taken from the literature were used to test
these predictions (table 2). To avoid the possible confounding effect of geographic
variation, species were included in the analyses only when large samples were available
from restricted geographic areas. Some widespread, possibly common species, such as
Lasionycteris noctivagans, were excluded for this reason. Samples were further restricted
